column3: Tian Di encompasses heaven and earth. This collection of furniture is made of clean lines and soft arcs, generous and open in spirit, ready to contain both the heavens and the earth. The Da Tian Di rocking chair applies this clean design concept to traditional Ming furniture, bringing it up to date with modern living. Walnut has a smooth, bright grain, like a tracery of inlaid gold, gleaming in the rich, dark wood. The SHANG XIA craftsmen spent over a year discovering the best way to join braided leather to the walnut frame. Special craft techniques make the wood stronger and longer-lasting, providing gentle support to the whole body, and revealing the deep craft that goes into the making of the chair. The process of construction, from the handling of the walnut timber through to the joinery, polishing and the selection and braiding of the leather requires nearly five months for each chair.  Every step in the construction of a Da Tian Di rocking chair must be performed with the highest precision. The result is a perfectly balanced chair: the lightest of breezes will start a gentle rocking. Take a moment to gently rock your cares away leaving a person, you, living a moment of peace in your own free space between heaven and earth.

Tian Di encompasses the heavens and the earth. This collection of furniture is made up of clean lines and soft arcs, generous and open in spirit, ready to contain the heavens and the earth. The Da Tian Di armchair is a light evolution of the traditional Ming "official's hat chair". It reverses the traditional Ming furniture concept of a rounded exterior and square centre and presents a square exterior and round interior. The result is a more modern line, revealing the deep craft that goes into its construction. SHANG XIA has ingeniously combined the simplicity and elegance of Ming furniture with the Western lounge concept, giving this new official's hat chair a soft seat and back, making it a more user-friendly experience. The Zitan is paired with high quality braided leather cushions. Tanners expertly slice whole cowhides into long strips, just 3.8mm wide. They are woven in a style similar to k'o-ssu silk tapestry, strip over strip, each piece entirely handmade, for a textured, living, breathing finish. The construction of each chair takes six to nine months with each step in the process being performed with needlepoint precision. The result is a finely crafted modern heirloom with a timeless appeal.

The SHANG XIA Da Tian Di collection draws inspiration from the rare and perfectly constructed Ming Dynasty “trestle desk”, to create an elegant and light desk in rich Zitan. As with all of the Da Tian Di collection, this desk is in the style of traditional Ming furniture, but it subverts the Ming concept of the round exterior/square centre to a square exterior and round interior. The result is a more modern line, revealing the deep craft that goes into its construction. The desk top is the same width as the supporting trestles, in the traditional frame-and-panel style, with a small seam between the frame and panel to allow the natural wood to breathe. This seam will subtly change with the humidity and climate, as if the desk were alive. The desk top rests lightly on the trestle supports which have drawers for stationery and documents. Zitan, precious and solid, has been polished by hand to a silken, glossy luster. Every step in the construction process must be performed with delicate precision. The process of construction, from the handling of the sandalwood timber through to the joinery and polishing, requires at least five months for every desk. The Da Tian Di desk should ideally be placed in front of a window. Pen and ink; fields and forests in front of you. Nature inspires; the images flow from your brush.

The SHANG XIA Da Tian Di collection is a reinvention of tea furniture, combining the tea tray and table in a single item. Made from Zitan wood, in a spare and classic form, providing elegance and utility. Reversing the traditional Ming furniture concept, of a rounded exterior and square center, the Da Tian Di collection presents a square exterior and round interior in a modern take on a classic aesthetic. Opening the table top reveals the tray and electric kettle. The process of construction requires at least 2,000 labor hours for each item, including hand crafted joints and polishing to provide a sliken glossy luster. The tray itself is make of Duan inkstone, one of the four most precious types of inkstone prized since antiquity and increasingly harder to find. The custom-made Da Tian Di collection of tea furniture casts a mantle of meditation across the reception space. It is for those who understand tea, who take the time to sit and savor their tea, and who receive guests with their finest tea.

column3: The dragon represents the traditional spirit of China. Its imperial splendor finds a modern expression in the SHANG XIA Dragon Cloud series: the pattern is inspired by the traditional dragon-scale motif, and its form and design animated by those soaring mythical beasts. Writhing over one another, their fierce majesty promises good fortune. The bamboo covered porcelain tea set consists of four cups with saucers and one teapot on a Zitan wood tray. It is a limited edition, with only 8 sets in existence. Evolving from the classic dragon-handled teacup, the two dragon handles on each cup have been stylized into a vivid modern arc form. Every piece in the Dragon Cloud set is created using the finest handcraft techniques. The bamboo fibers are less than half a millimeter in width, and are gilded in five layers of 18k gold dust with minute accuracy, then tightly woven over white porcelain that has been fired at an extremely high temperature. The gilt covers every inch of the bamboo in a gleaming finish, so smooth and even that it seems an organic part of the material. With its pure gold crescent handle, the design is timeless. The Dragon Cloud set represents over 1,000 hours of painstaking work by master craftsman. It is a collector's item, but its elegance and textures may also be appreciated in the daily ritual of tea drinking.

It has the quality of a display piece or it may become part of your everyday tea ritual.

Entertaining at home provides a relaxed environment bringing people together around the heart of tea and the home. Whether the tea pot, the tea set or the set of vases are cosseted in bamboo weaving or purely in ceramic, the collection through the shape of its traditional “bridge” handles connects each of us to the warmth of hospitality and friends. The bamboo, is expertly shaved into strands of less than 0.5 mm and woven around the ceramic ware.
The gong fu tea set, a set of mini tea cups to inhale the fragrance of tea and savor the flavor of tea, is fired in fine porcelain, each piece carefully glazed in translucent white.
The general tea set and trio of vases, are each expertly finished with hand carved thin bamboo strips woven in mesh. It takes days to completely weave one teapot. The woven bamboo also helps to ensure the tea remains warm.

The SHANG XIA Shan Shui collection is carved by hand from flawless raw agate into delicate round bowls, presented on a tray of Zitan. With your choice of moss or smoky agate, each bowl is carved and polished from a single piece of agate, requiring over 80 hours of patient labor. With its natural finish, each item in the Shan Shui series has its own pattern, like the brush strokes of a great calligrapher, turning each piece into a unique landscape. When sipping from Shan Shui vessels, even the purest of water seems intoxicating.

The Twilight series is a set of wooden cases in rich Zitan wood, inlaid with delicate carved bamboo. They may be used on a dresser, for jewellery, for cosmetics, for perfume, or as a pen case in the study. Skillfully interwoven the traditional sayagata pattern with the SHANGXIA logo to create a unique carved bamboo motif for the Twilight series. The bamboo carvers bring concentration and years of honed technique to their work. Using tools they make themselves, they split the bamboo into 0.5mm-thin strips, then cut 0.5mm-wide notches, and divide the strips into 5mm sections. Then, patiently and precisely, they piece together these sections, no larger than a grain of rice, into a composite image. A 10 square centimeters carving contains over 1,000 tiny sections, placed with such accuracy that the individual pieces become invisible and melt into an organic whole. As with traditional window screens, the design creates an airy and satisfying interplay of light and shade. Meanwhile, the form of these irregularly sized cases imitates the graceful lines of Ming Dynasty furniture; seen under the crystal twilight, a classical past seems to emerge once again. The poet Su Shi once wrote, "Dancing in the half-light, you are far from this world." Twilight exists in a space outside time.

The game of Go (Weiqi) was one of the four arts that every gentleman scholar of China had to master (The other three are calligraphy, painting and the zither). Go was seen as a reflection of the Dao, and playing Go was considered as a path to greater understanding. The Wan Xiang collection is inspired by the universality of Go, and presents a Go set in warm-grained Rosewood and fine agate. The board borrows the clean lines of Ming Dynasty furniture. The fine grid of Go, representing the entire universe, is carved into a lovingly polished Rosewood block. The edges of the board and star points are inlaid in white brass. The two materials have been carefully selected and artfully combined by our craftsmen so that neither time nor changes in environment will break the bond between them. The precious wood and hard metal are locked together for eternity. The Go stones are presented in Rosewood bowls with agate lids. Each of the 360 stones is an agate droplet, specially selected by SHANG XIA for evenness of grain. Each stone is identical in size, smooth to the touch; placed on the board, they engage in their dance of yin and yang, illuminating and enlightening our world. Each Wan Xiang Go set takes a full three months to carve and polish to perfection. In Chinese legend, Go is known as the “forgetting game” - a player can forget his worries and even transcend this world. The thrust and parry of Go is the best way to pit your wits against a friend; when alone, the poet says, you can rap stones on board till the lamps burn out.

SHANG XIA creatively applies Chinese water-color paintings onto the "Wish" poker cards. In this artistically designed deck of cards, traditional patterns have been replaced by Chinese cultural symbols, Cloud of Ganoderma, Bodhi Leaf, Red Peach, Taihu Rock...these symbols are simple yet convey profound meanings. The cards, each design hand painted, are presented in an exquisitely hand carved Zitan box. Available in regular and large sizes, the large size is limited to just 100 sets. This collectible work of art will ensure the joy of playing as well as the appreciation of Chinese culture.

Mahjong is a traditional Chinese game. The SHANG XIA Jun Zi collection is inspired by traditional Chinese carry boxes. Nestled on five levels, the Jun Zi mahjong case contains 4 boxes of mahjong tiles and racks, a box of chips, chip holder and dice. With your choice of tiles in precious Indian sandalwood and Zitan, marked with geometric abstraction pattern, your every game will be infused with a gentle, natural, elegant aroma. Time and space seem to be manipulated at the fingertips of the players. Over 2,000 hours of craft have gone into making each mahjong set.

Inspired from sacred vessels used in imperial offerings, the contemporary lacquer vases and candleholders, a set of four, provide the ideal accent “For Happiness”. According to long traditions in China, “four happiness-es” represent the four happy times in life: marriage, academic achievement, friendship, and fortune. The soft patina of the lacquer exudes warmth and comfort of home.

Created by expertly skilled master craftsmen, using similar techniques to those used when hand-felting fabric for Mongolian yurts, these sculpted garments are made in felt. Inspired by traditional Han dynasty clothing, this collection reflects the traditional elegance of Chinese style. Each garment is unique and sculpted into a seamless shape to create a 3-dimensional garment in felt of Mongolian cashmere. Wrapped in style, one will surely remain warm in winter.

Skilled master craftsmen create these cashmere garments and accessories using techniques similar to the hand-felting of fabric for Mongolian yurts. Spinners select the rarest quality Mongolian cashmere, then knead, rub, roll them into a form-fitting shape.  Sculpture scarves have cleverly upturned seams to create a complex texture. The hand embroidered bright silk threads add colourful accents whilst ensuring the seams retain their flat, smooth shape. The result is a Sculpture scarf that is richly textured, harmonious, complete and unique as a cloud in the sky.

The SHANG XIA He Qi collection of luxury cashmere overcoats is exquisitely tailored to produce the best possible fit for both men and women. The materials are supplied exclusively from the world's best wool-producing latitudes. Several rounds of sorting by hand are required to find the finest wool which is then spun into yarn of unparalleled smoothness and resilience. The name He Qi comes from a Ming poem: "The forces mingle (he qi) in the Heaven; the earth knows great peace". The “Tao Te Ching” says: “All things combine to achieve harmony”. The mingling of forces is the great combination of yin and yang, the generative elements of this world. It is one of the most fundamental and most Chinese philosophical notions. This collection is inspired by the combination of two dissimilar materials. The shoulders of the ladies' range sport a daring and unusual inclusion of goatskin leather. The men's range is distinguished by its rib knit inclusions, bringing an element of softness to its Confucian formality. The He Qi collection updates the lines of the traditional Han Dynasty style robe. It retains the broad, comfortable body and sleeves, while adding discreet belt loops to the women's range for a touch of professional elegance. He Qi: for wisdom, for enlightenment, for harmony, and for style.

The Jin Yi collection is inspired by traditional Chinese winter wear, the cotton coat. SHANG XIA replaces traditional cotton wadding with silk to keep out the cold and enhance softness. Every coat is lined with superior pure silk and with our characteristic attention to detail we have matched the lining and exterior colours perfectly. The ladies' coats are reversible, to match any outfit. Arrow-straight seams are sewn by the long-experienced hands of seamstresses who work with love and concentration to ensure not even the slightest deviation. As always, it is the detail that brings the design alive, with motifs embroidered by hand into the side pockets. Jin Yi coats are available in three colours, to suit every personality and every mood. Elegantly and softly, Jin Yi will keep you warm throughout the winter.

The SHANG XIA One collection is made from the finest Mongolian cashmere, soft and warm. Taking inspiration from traditional Chinese tailoring, the collection elevates the cardigan to its simplest incarnation, with sleeves and body cut together from one piece of two-sided, full-needle knit material. Each item in the One collection is reversible, with different colours inside and out to suit your mood. Worn one way, you are light and casual; worn the other, you are sombre and self-contained. The sleeves can also be folded up for a lively colour combination. The seams are sewn by our expert seamstresses to perfection, giving the garment an understated glamour. The men's One coat has the distinctive SHANG XIA wooden buttons; the ladies' range comes with a Zitan brooch. With its simple lines and individual detail and style, the One collection will become a staple of your wardrobe. It can be an outfit in itself or be paired with other items. Wearing the One collection, you will experience confidence, simplicity and natural poise.

Woven from raw silk, the fabric embodies the natural, original and coarse feel of linen. Created from unprocessed silk cocoons, the semi hard and transparent fabric is what is known as raw silk. Holding their shape strongly, these outer garments are finished with the finest of care, allowing one to express the traditional elegance of scholarly gentlemen. The fabric, of natural colors, has tea vein-like inclusions.

Woven from traditional Chinese raw silk, each hand dyed piece is unique. Whether embroidered with gold or silver threads, or hand threaded with cashmere, each shawl is a work of art. It takes 3 months to produce each Shang Xia shawl. From dyeing to folding to sewing, each is individually hand crafted. The shawl can be worn in multiple ways depending on one’s mood. In ancient times, this type of shawl was worn by aristocratic ladies and was a reflection of their elegance and style.

Woven from cashmere and cotton, this men’s collection is both soft and comfortable. 

Woven from beginning to end in one continuous thread, it is an outstanding technical achievement, evenly finished with no seams. Inspired by Han dynasty costumes, the simple line, color and cross over tie, are the model of confidence and nature of traditional Chinese elegance.

The SHANG XIA Joy collection is made from the finest Mongolian cashmere. Cut to resemble the Qipao and Chinese blouse, this collection is actually designed using the most modern tailoring technology. The trim, collar, placket and knot work buttons are machine sewed to the highest standard. The plain collection is knitted using the distinctive rice stitch while the knot work button crochet is hand stitched. The design of the Joy collection is playful, and evokes, all is illusion, and the only important thing is your personal enlightenment. This ladies’ collection provides the grace of the Qipao in the softness of woven cashmere. Easy to wear, these items will be your first call for warmth during winter.

Using the finest natural materials, the Essence series presents jewellery in the Eastern idiom: warm, smooth and elegant, evolved from centuries of Chinese craftsmanship. SHANG XIA has revived an art form of the imperial house - filigree inlay. Gold threads and diamonds are inset into fine Zitan wood. The wood is polished, the design is scored in and then the gold filigree is carefully inlaid into the surface. These two contrasting materials seamlessly crafted together as if nature had formed them that way. The collision of textures creates an “other worldly” luminance. The passage of time is marked clearly in the grain of the wood giving the Essence series the weight of wisdom accumulated over years of life. Warmed by the neck of the wearer, Essence exudes a quiet, perfumed grace.

Inner painted snuff bottles were first created during the Qing Dynasty and are known as the “Sorcerer’s Art”. Combining calligraphy, painting and carving, they are concentrated expression of several traditional Chinese arts. The brilliance of their form inspired the SHANGXIA Ling Long collection. With curved bamboo brushes just 4mm wide, they paint the inner surfaces of each crystal. To achieve their delicate brushwork, they must often change brushes, threading them through the tiny opening. The artists work in reverse, constantly visualizing how their work will be seen face-on. Working with a curved brush through the tiny aperture requires intense concentration. The artists’ creation of landscapes and images inside the crystal pieces has been called sorcery. The Ling Long series can be used for display items or may be worn as a pendant that is refined and a little magical.

Layer upon shimmering layer of scales, light and translucent, weighty and lifelike. Wear them, and feel the verve of the dragon's jaunty stride.

This collection of 6 miniature treasures, delicately crafted from traditional Chinese materials, symbolize the refinement and pursuit of unusual collectible baubles. Based on water pots used by scholars, where water continually drips, like fortune continually flowing, the miniature teapots are made from jade and agate and each is named individually; “Fortune”, “Wealth”, “Longevity”, “Happiness”, “Joy”, and “Luck”

Fortune: Similar in shape to an ancient granary, round and full, the teapot symbolizes a multitude of fortune.

Wealth: Similar in shape to ancient Chinese square coins, the full teapot represents overflowing wealth

Longevity: Similar in shape to the shell of a tortoise, the tortoise shell symbolizes longevity

Happiness: Similar in shape to a floral bloom, the overlapping petals symbolize unending happiness. 

Joy: Round in shape, the uninterrupted sides symbolize fullness in life and joy

Luck: May the teapot always be filled with auspiciousness and unending luck.

Delicately carved from a 4 kilo piece of Hotian jade, Suzhou craftsmen have deftly carved the stone for more than 4 months to create the “Jade Treasure”. The name in Chinese is also a homonym for great wealth and hence the bearer of great fortune. 

Carving of jade is a more than 50-step process and in order to carve so finely the craftsman must be highly skilled. The natural inclusions and skin are skillfully used to enhance the design. This museum quality jade art object is unique and without comparison.

The SHANG XIA Da Tian Di collection is a reinvention of tea furniture, combining the tea tray and table in a single item. Made from Zitan wood, in a spare and classic form, providing elegance and utility. Reversing the traditional Ming furniture concept, of a rounded exterior and square center, the Da Tian Di collection presents a square exterior and round interior in a modern take on a classic aesthetic. Opening the table top reveals the tray and electric kettle. The process of construction requires at least 2,000 labor hours for each item, including hand crafted joints and polishing to provide a sliken glossy luster. The tray itself is make of Duan inkstone, one of the four most precious types of inkstone prized since antiquity and increasingly harder to find. The custom-made Da Tian Di collection of tea furniture casts a mantle of meditation across the reception space. It is for those who understand tea, who take the time to sit and savor their tea, and who receive guests with their finest tea.

“Rocking in heaven and earth, words no more.”

Tian Di encompasses the heavens and the earth. This collection of furniture is made up of clean lines and soft arcs, generous and open in spirit, as if ready to contain heaven and earth within itself. The Da Tian Di rocking chair brings clean lines to traditional Ming furniture, bringing it into a modern living context whilst revealing the extensive craftsmanship that goes into its construction. The SHANG XIA master carpenters have experimented with dozens of forms to find the perfect line and arc. The solid Zitan frame and seat of finest woven rattan provide gentle support to the whole body. Special techniques make the wood stronger and longer-lasting. The process of construction, from the handling of the Zitan timber through to the joinery and polishing, requires a full 5,000 hours work for every chair, and every step in the process must be done with have needlepoint precision. The result is a masterpiece of detail and sensitivity. Even the slightest breeze, breath, or the beating of your heart will set off a sympathetic, dreamy rocking. Take a moment out of your schedule; feel calm and comfort in your own space between the heavens and the earth.

Gold leaves are carefully plated and polished over the soft patina of the lacquer, each piece requiring over 900 hours of work, exudes warmth and comfort into your home.

SHANG XIA's work with the painters of Jinshan has allowed them to imaginatively evolve their use of materials, and to print this bright collection on silk and cashmere as commissioned by SHANG XIA.

The Minstrel collection is inspired by the painting The Entourage of Emperor Kangxi by the Qing Dynasty painter Wang Hui. It was commissioned specially for the opening of the SHANG XIA Space in Hongqiao Airport. The cloth is woven from high quality cashmere and silk, with a clear grain and a delicate feel. The colors are bold and vital. We hope this scarf will add a moment of joy to your travels, and a moment of escape to the most urban lifestyle.

The SHANG XIA Joy collection is made from the finest Mongolian cashmere. Cut to resemble the Qipao and Chinese blouse, this collection is actually designed using the most modern tailoring technology. The trim, collar, placket and knot work buttons are machine sewed to the highest standard. The plain collection is knitted using the distinctive rice stitch while the knot work button crochet is hand stitched. The design of the Joy collection is playful, and evokes, all is illusion, and the only important thing is your personal enlightenment. This ladies’ collection provides the grace of the Qipao in the softness of woven cashmere. Easy to wear, these items will be your first call for warmth during winter.

Drawing on the humdrum perfection of the bamboo basket, SHANG XIA has created a textured leather echo of woven bamboo, with the same living grain and structure. The LAN YUE collection takes design deeper into the detail and material of the handbag than ever before. Leather and bamboo, two mature crafts, engage and blend in the LAN YUE collection, bringing new challenges for our craftsmen, and a new outlook for the handbag.

The Sun & Moon collection selects the finest, softest double-sided cashmere, with a fancy hand-stitched hem that gathers the cloth into the perfect line. The result is a powerful, expressionist statement of the material. In Chinese philosophy, the sun and moon represent yang and yin. The I Ching tells us: "The sun and moon have their place in the sky." This means that the sun and moon are the way of the universe; their duality creates endless meaning in the world. The Sun & Moon collection offers the duality of a reversible coat. It can be worn either way out to suit the needs of the occasion and your changing world. The men's collection is inspired by the traditional buttoned gown, repurposed into a greatcoat and a blazer. Both garments are presented in reserved tones, selected to speak of quiet resolve and still waters that run deep. The women's collection adapts the classic line of the ancient shenyi gown, breaking with the old design at the shoulders, and offering either a one-piece sleeved coat or a bodywarmer. Bright as the sunshine, graceful as light, the colors were chosen for their overtones of warmth and pleasure. With Sun & Moon you are clothed in light and shade, free to float the length and breadth of this world.

The SHANG XIA Moonlight collection offers a classic cut in luxurious raw silk, soft as a whisper and cool as a breeze. The seams are uniquely finished with Jali stitching, a technique named after an Indian tradition of window making. Careful detailing provides the utmost comfort in summer. In contrasting black and white, with creamy white and lustrous dark jade buttons, this is an elegant round neck shirt with an understated sheen. The ivory-white silk gives off a soft glow, rippling sensuously like a summer breeze.

The SHANG XIA One collection is made from the finest Mongolian cashmere, soft and warm. Taking inspiration from traditional Chinese tailoring, the collection refines the cardigan to its simplest form, with sleeves and body cut together from one piece of cloth. A seam elegantly joins the front and rear panels, running along the line of the sleeves and down to the lower hem forming an elegant understated pattern. The cardigan is matched with a belt but can also be worn with a tie. With its simple lines and individual detail and style, it can be an outfit in itself or be paired with other items.

Skilled master craftsmen create these cashmere garments using techniques similar to the hand-felting of fabric for Mongolian yurts. Inspired by traditional Han dynasty clothing, this collection reflects the traditional elegance of Chinese style. “Sculpture” is cut with great precision from the rarest quality of Mongolian cashmere, then it is rubbed, rolled and formed into a seamless but form-fitting item. Two different tones of cashmere are marvelously knit into one by the weavers' two-handed technique. They create a natural line of color around the collar, lapels and hem, giving the robe style and definition. No seams, no sew-lines, complete and unique as a cloud in the sky. Like the dawn that floods the heavens; like a hug on a winter's day; “Sculpture”, dense and warm.

Yak grow a thick woolen coat to survive the long winters of the Tibetan plains. In the warmth of spring, herders comb out the soft down, grade it, and use it to make the finest clothing. Yak wool is strong and dense and maintains its natural tone even when dyed. The SHANG XIA Wanderer collection is a combination of three tones of hand spun and hand dyed yarn, artfully woven to form this exclusive SHANG XIA fabric. Every Wanderer coat is carefully edged with fine lambskin. It took over 400 hours of painstaking attention to detail. Instead of the multiple panels of modern clothe-making, the Wanderer is based on Chinese traditional dress tailoring, so that the overcoats exude solidity and unity. They are form fitting, but comfortably roomy, like the long cadence of a herding song ringing out across the high plains.

Derived from the classic concept of “yin” and “yang” (male and female energy), each pendant is part of a whole embodying polar yet interconnected forces. Carved and polished smooth in 18K gold and 18K platinum respectively, the Couple collection embraces the strength and commitment of life energy forces.

The SHANG XIA Garden collection includes pendants of Zi­tan, white jade, agate, gold, silver – and, of course, original Taihu Rock, prized over the ages for representing wisdom and immortality. They twist and turn, intriguing and wild, solid and hollow, a surprising form from every side and angle. The Garden collection brings the same sense of contemplative meditation which inspired ancient philosophers and poets, to a single tiny pen­dant to be worn over your heart, inspiring your soul.

Entertaining at home provides a relaxed environment bringing people together around the heart of tea and the home. Whether the tea pot, the tea set or the set of vases are cosseted in bamboo weaving or purely in ceramic, the collection through the shape of its traditional “bridge” handles connects each of us to the warmth of hospitality and friends. The bamboo, is expertly shaved into strands of less than 0.5 mm and woven around the ceramic ware.

The gong fu tea set, a set of mini tea cups to inhale the fragrance of tea and savor the flavor of tea, is fired in fine porcelain, each piece carefully glazed in translucent white. 

The general tea set and trio of vases, are each expertly finished with hand carved thin bamboo strips woven in mesh. It takes days to completely weave one teapot. The woven bamboo also helps to ensure the tea remains warm.

The SHANG XIA Ding tea set draws its inspiration from the traditional three-footed ding. With a teapot, steeping cup and six drinking cups, it brings an element of ritual every time tea is drunk. Every item in the set is fired at over 1300 degrees, giving the porcelain a natural jade-like gloss. The designers dispensed with the two large handles to make this ancient form a little lighter. The result is a modern style that is simple and airy. The full, smooth forms fit the hand however you hold them, making the steeping and drinking of tea a natural, instinctive process: elegant, hospitable and deeply traditional.

column2: Jun Zi Ming Yue Tea Box
column3: The bright moon shines between the pines, The clear spring water flows over the stones. Wang Wei (Tang Dynasty), "Mountain Life on an Autumn Evening". The moon is a constant theme in classical Chinese poetry. A dim, restful, expansive vision of moonlight saturates the imagination and the philosophy of many poets. The Yue tea box, part of SHANG XIA's Junzi collection, was inspired by classical carry cases, with their fine, self-contained designs. Like the bright, clear moon, they represent beauty and peace. The box is in three layers, each layer perfectly structured and functional. The box's contents can be stored safely and logically, so that they are easy to find, simple to stow and light to carry. The bottom layer holds the teapot in a shaped cushion. The middle layer is divided into four quarters two snugly hold four teacups, and has a shaped rim which allows the tea tray to fit perfectly on top within the lid. The handle is carved from a single piece of walnut with an attractive arch. While carrying the box, it locks the layers securely in place. A dragon-scale pattern is carved on the surface of the tea tray, and it has a space inside it, allowing it to serve the functions of both the traditional tea tray and the water reservoir. The tray is made of Corian, a light and durable material, in the color of tea.

column2: Le Chant du Thé Arhat Tea Cups
column3: The luminous porcelain of the “arhat” tea cups is decorated with motifs of longevity peaches, Lingzhi clouds and leaves of the Bodhi tree, each image painted by hand by an artist with over ten years of experience.

column3: Mahjong is a traditional Chinese game. The SHANG XIA Jun Zi collection is inspired by traditional Chinese carry boxes. Nestled on five levels, the Jun Zi mahjong case contains 4 boxes of mahjong tiles and racks, a box of chips, chip holder and dice. With your choice of tiles in precious Indian sandalwood and Zitan, marked with geometric abstraction pattern, your every game will be infused with a gentle, natural, elegant aroma. Time and space seem to be manipulated at the fingertips of the players. Over 2,000 hours of craft have gone into making each mahjong set.

SHANG XIA Le chant du Thé crockery brings warm colors to a modern evolution of tableware, filled with flavor and companionship. It offers a generous provision of plates, serving dishes and bowls. The whole set lends refinement and class to the dining table. The unique designs on the plates are taken from paintings inspired by the Confucian Temple, the Temple of Heaven and the bamboo slips. They bring the wisdom of ancient architecture and handicrafts into the ceramic, and the bold colors remind us of the great sweep of China's culinary tradition. Let a simple meal take on centuries of flavor and meaning.

The Twlight series is a set of wooden cases in rich Zitan wood, inlaid with delicate carved bamboo. They may be used on a dresser, for jewellery, for cosmetics, for perfume, or as a pen case in the study. Skillfully interwoven the traditional sayagata pattern with the SHANGXIA logo creates a unique carved bamboo motif for the Twlight series. The bamboo carvers bring concentration and years of honed technique to their work. Using tools they make themselves, they split the bamboo into 0.5mm-thin strips, then cut 0.5mm-wide notches, and divide the strips into 5mm sections. Then, patiently and precisely, they piece together these sections, no larger than a grain of rice, into a composite image. A 10 square centimeters carving contains over 1,000 tiny sections, placed with such accuracy that the individual pieces become invisible and melt into an organic whole. As with traditional window screens, the design creates an airy and satisfying interplay of light and shade. Meanwhile, the form of these irregularly sized cases imitates the graceful lines of Ming Dynasty furniture; seen under the crystal Twlight, a classical past seems to emerge once again. The poet Su Shi once wrote, "Dancing in the half-light, you are far from this world." Twlight exists in a space outside time.

The SHANG XIA Wufu series draws on the Qing Dynasty flared vase form, but allows the vase to sleekly separate into a set of plates and containers. We blended two traditions, using lacquer to recreate the beauty of porcelain. This series uses a palette of five colors to echo the “Wufu”, each associated with one of the great porcelain kilns: Ru, Guan, Ge, Ding and Jun. The crackled porcelain effect on the outside of the vase was recreated using a painstaking technique of eggshell and lacquer. The eggshell is carefully cracked and pieced precisely back together. The pieces must be of uniform size, and must fit seamlessly together. Only the steadiest and most experienced lacquerworkers can do this delicate work. The gilded interior involves a slow finishing process, then the minute work of piecing gilt onto surface. It takes calmness and dedication to align the pieces seamlessly together. The color is infused into the lacquer, so the process of repeated polishing and burnishing brings it out in a warm gloss, understated and classic. The “Wufu” are: long life, prosperity, health, virtue and a peaceful passing. They represent a long life, well lived.

Tian Di encompasses the heavens and the earth. This collection of furniture is made up of clean lines and soft arcs, generous and open in spirit, ready to contain the heavens and the earth. The Da Tian Di armchair is a light evolution of the traditional Ming "official's hat chair". It reverses the traditional Ming furniture concept of a rounded exterior and square centre and presents a square exterior and round interior. The result is a more modern line, revealing the deep craft that goes into its construction. SHANG XIA has ingeniously combined the simplicity and elegance of Ming furniture with the Western lounge concept, giving this new official's hat chair a soft seat and back, making it a more user-friendly experience. The Zitan is paired with high quality braided leather cushions. Tanners expertly slice whole cowhides into long strips, just 3.8mm wide. They are woven in a style similar to k'o-ssu silk tapestry, strip over strip, each piece entirely handmade, for a textured, living, breathing finish. The construction of each chair takes six to nine months with each step in the process being performed with needlepoint precision. The result is a finely crafted modern heirloom with a timeless appeal.

The SHANG XIA Da Tian Di collection is a reinvention of tea furniture, combining the tea tray and table in a single item. Made from Zitan wood, in a spare and classic form, providing elegance and utility. Reversing the traditional Ming furniture concept, of a rounded exterior and square center, the Da Tian Di collection presents a square exterior and round interior in a modern take on a classic aesthetic. Opening the table top reveals the tray and electric kettle. The process of construction requires at least 2,000 labor hours for each item, including hand crafted joints and polishing to provide a sliken glossy luster. The tray itself is make of Duan inkstone, one of the four most precious types of inkstone prized since antiquity and increasingly harder to find. The custom-made Da Tian Di collection of tea furniture casts a mantle of meditation across the reception space. It is for those who understand tea, who take the time to sit and savor their tea, and who receive guests with their finest tea.

The SHANG XIA Junzi screen is a traditionally-constructed four-panel foldable screen. It consists of wooden frames and embroidered scrolls, which can be rolled up or left down as needed, just like a painting. The scrolls, designed exclusively for this item, are in subdued tones with a sense of density, easily matching any household decoration. The mobility and ease of adjustment mean that the screen can be used in any season; in winter, particularly, it can shape a warm oasis. The frame is designed on the principle of square exterior and rounded interior, with a coherent, simple form. The panels can be turned to any angle as required, and will remain stable whatever the formation. They can also be folded away for ease of storage. The four panels each have a unique width and shape; together they possess a harmony and rhythm. Simple elements, combined with grace like blocks of color in an abstract painting.
